title: I Hate Tanking,...
body:
The moment I get a 5 man ult with ~~5~~ 4 allies near me and only half the team ever joins. I don't get how you do it. This is why I jungle assassins. It frustrates me every single time they wait, walking back and fourth until they see you're still alive for at least 5 seconds before joining.

I really don't have the patience for that. Props to tank mains, your patience is that of a saint.

Support gives me headaches, too. When my ADC is paying attention, I actually find it very enjoyable and fulfilling. When they don't, I feel miserable. For instance, if I stun the enemy ADC right as they walk up to a minion to CS it, they're close enough for you to get a free AA. I'll ping first, and yeah you won't be able to do it all the time, I get that.

But I swear some ADCs go out of their way to NEVER attack when you CC the enemy carry. It's like they tunnel so hard on CSing they ignore every other lane mechanic. It makes me **SO** thankful when I support a good ADC, because I have a lot of respect for the difficulty of what they do. I just wish it didn't bone me over so badly when they haven't got a clue. I'm not a good enough support to carry bad lanes :x.

Ask any support main and they'll tell you the same. Tank and support are the most team-reliant roles. They are also the expected ward-providers and the ones who are always at the lowest levels.

Whenever I play as either role I feel like I spend all game running around the map trying to put out fires.
It's funny we never find this support in game.

Us support mains are in roughly the same boat. We can't do anything without backup from our team, but it's difficult to coordinate them properly. Nevertheless, I still love playing support Janna. Peels forever!

But I get where your coming from man, I know how that feels, especially when they start telling you "your not tanky enough" when your close to almost 4k hp...then it's just like, wtf.

End game 20k build Shyvana ulting into five enemies. No way I wasn't tanky enough >:L. It's just so frustrating. They regularly blew 2+ ults on me or else their ADC gets zoned from the fight entirely.

Especially end game, joining a tank's initiate and losing is FAR BETTER than not joining and letting two allies die for nothing. If you take their ADC and AD assassin down and the rest are wounded, even one survivor can stop a push. 3v5 can't stop sh*t.

I like tanking. For me, few things are more enjoyable than watching the entire enemy focus you in utter desperation to kill you and fail.

A few champions are really good at tanking and dealing damage at the same time. You just need to know how to properly build them, and most people don't know how, because they associate damage with stat numbers too much. My favorite weapon to build for tanks (like Braum, Volibear, Nautilus and Thresh) is Wit's End. It deals 42 magic damage and provides a decent amount of magic resist and steals more from the enemy (a stat most neglect to build). Tanks that specialize in dealing magic damage through their skills (Rammus, Sejuani, Zac, Nautilus, Amumu) benefit from building LIandri's Torment as their primary damage item (though Thornmail works just as well for Rammus). Tanks that have a lot of basic attack focus (Nautilus, Volibear, Braum, Vi, Udyr, Trundle) should focus on upping their DPS and maximizing what they can do with on-hit effects (Sheen items, Wit's End, Black Cleaver, Frozen Mallet).

In the end, though, yes, they are meant to be team players, and allies should know when you're ready to charge the enemy.

Do not play tanks in low elo. Playing tanks at higher elos is fine, because they have the brains to actually understand to follow up on engages etc.

I disagree with this; well, not about the teams not following up, because that totally can happen, but a team with no tanks gets wrecked really easily.  Almost every team in low elo needs more tanks than it has.  But you have to focus on peel and countering dives more so than trying to engage for a wombo combo, because a lot of the time it's not going to happen.

If they were capable of learning not to dive someone protected by a tank, they wouldn't stay in low elo.  (Of course, if my ideas worked consistently, neither would I...)

I think a lot of the problem is communication.  It's quite hard to get everybody coordinated when the tank decided to initiate unless you're on Skype or something.

This is a good example of why a lot of times the team doesnt follow into that "perfect initiation", becauses its not. A lot of tank players fall into the trap of "my team is following my lead and watching me" so when he/she thinks its time to go in they expect the team to follow. But there are other factors at play. Things the tank can miss. For example; you are facing a 5v4 advantage and say BOOM, time to go in. But maybe you missed seeing that assassin poking his head out of the jungle in the rear. Your team is backing out and now you are out of position. You go in, they say "shit" and try and follow. 8-9 seconds later, you are dead and they are finally joining the fight.

Dont get me wrong, there are times when it IS the right time to go in and the team does get it (bad positioning, poor situational awareness, etc). I 'mained' tanks for most of seasons 1-4 so I get it. But I also enjoy playing other roles so have been able to see things from all sides.

In fact the tanks in the current jungle dont even have good clear, compared to assassins or bruisers. That's not true, most tanks can solo kill people, it's just that you can't solo kill people with a full tank build. And it's normal because that wouldn't be balanced. People never adapted to that and that's why tanks are not popular.

The three mentioned have heavy burst, great numbers and can duel. They dont even need to build full tank to survive because they have mobility to be in the fight as little as possible and make incredible impact. Bruisers do too much and tanks arent compensated for their lack of damage.

That's another wrong assumption, the tanks i'm talking about are nautilus, sejuani, amumu, cho'gath too. The damage of these guys are all about using all their cd on their targets and to kill them or to be killed because they have really poor dps.

The biggest assumption you are doing is when you imply that you either build defense or build offense and not a mix of both. But it's exactly what you have to do as a tank to be relevant. To build damage to not be a wet noodle and a lot of defense to survive in the middle of the fight.

Start building the proper items on tanks and you will see that you can deals close to as much damage as a bruisers while being really tanky.

While it sucks to land the perfect ult and then have your team not follow up, the blame cannot solely be place on your team.

A lot of 'perfect ults' are Flash-engagements, which can put you too far ahead of your team.  As the initiator, it is your job to look for both the perfect engage, and to ensure that your team is in a position to follow up.  

I have seen Amumu flash+bandagetoss+ultimates completely go to waste, because nobobdy else on the team can even hope to follow up.

the thing about playing a tanky frontliner is... you still need to dodge stuff as well.  you can't just charge straight in and facetank everything.  you should only be eating skillshots if it's specifically to bodyblock for a carry.
